def_en: Blood is the red liquid that flows inside your body, which you can see if you cut yourself.
You can use blood to refer to the race or social class of someone's parents or ancestors.
If you say that there is bad blood between people, you mean that they have argued about something and dislike each other.
If you say that people are baying for blood, you mean that they are demanding that someone should be hurt or punished.
See also:blue-blooded; If you say that someone has blue blood, you mean that they are from a family that has a high social rank.

def_cn: 使怒不可遏；使怒火中烧
def_en: If you say that something makes your blood boil, you are emphasizing that it makes you very angry.

def_cn: 冷酷无情地；冷血地；残忍地
def_en: See also:cold-blooded; If something violent and cruel is done in cold blood, it is done deliberately and in an unemotional way.

def_cn: 使人不寒而栗；令人毛骨悚然
def_en: If you say that something makes your blood run cold or makes your blood freeze, you mean that it makes you feel very frightened.

def_cn: 手上沾了…的血；对…的死难辞其咎
def_en: If you say that someone has a person's blood on their hands, you mean that they are responsible for that person's death.

def_cn: 天生的；遗传的；生来就有的
def_en: If a quality or talent is in your blood, it is part of your nature, and other members of your family have it too.

def_cn: 新鲜血液；新生力量；新成员
def_en: You can use the expressions new blood ,fresh blood, or young blood to refer to people who are brought into an organization to improve it by thinking of new ideas or new ways of doing things.

def_cn: 向石取血，缘木求鱼（比喻很难办到或徒劳无功）
def_en: If you say that doing something such as getting information or persuading someone to talk to you is like getting blood out of a stone or getting blood from a stone, you are emphasizing that it is very difficult and that people are not being very helpful. In American English, you can also say that it is like getting blood out of a turnip .
If you say that someone sweats blood trying to do something, you are emphasizing that they try very hard to do it.

def_cn: 取得初步胜利；最先占上风
def_en: If you say that someone draws first blood, you mean that they have had a success at the beginning of a competition or conflict.
If you refer to something as involving blood, sweat, and tears, you mean that it is a very hard thing to do and requires a lot of effort.

def_cn: 血浓于水；家人总比外人亲
def_en: People say 'blood is thicker than water' when they mean that their loyalty to their family is greater than their loyalty to anyone else.
flesh and blood→see: flesh;  own flesh and blood→see: flesh;
